title: Letter: Think of the industries that may have been saved
text:
In the Babel-like world of phone connectors to which the EU is trying to bring order (“A tangle of cables is the price for Apple's innovation”, Opinion, June 11), industries and regulators are required to balance the need for innovation with the feelings of the majority of consumers, who don't actually like obsolescence and want retro-compatibility.

The majority who aren't the early adopters, and are frustrated to discover they can no longer get the plug/widget/case for the piece of tech they bought three years ago, are the ones who resent throwing it out.

Remember too the corporate egos. Betamax and VHS home video standards, developed by rivals who would not work together. Home audio was littered with mutually-incompatible systems.

Had Canon, Nikon, Minolta, Kodak and Fuji — who developed the photo industry's last point-and-shoot analogue film format (APS) — made it retro-compatible with 35mm (at least in film stock width) the photo-processing industry would have been more willing to embrace it. Today 35mm film is still made; APS is not.

David Healey
Burntisland, Fife, UK
